Text: Sing for joy to God our strength; shout aloud to the God of Jacob!
Context: This verse calls for jubilant praise, indicating communal celebration and worship.

Text: Begin the music, strike the tambourine, play the melodious harp and lyre.
Context: The verse emphasizes the importance of musical instruments in worship, suggesting a festive atmosphere.

Text: Sound the ram’s horn at the New Moon, and when the moon is full, on the day of our festival;
Context: The reference to the New Moon and full moon festivals indicates a time for remembrance and celebration according to Israelite religious practice.

Text: This is a decree for Israel, an ordinance of the God of Jacob.
Context: The verse represents a command that signifies the religious duties of the Israelites, ordained by God.

Text: He established it as a statute for Joseph when he went out against the land of Egypt. There I heard a language I did not understand.
Context: The verse recalls a historical moment for the people of Joseph (Israel), relating to their deliverance from Egypt and their encounter with a foreign culture.

Text: I removed his shoulder from the burden; his hands were freed from the basket.
Context: The speaker, God, recalls easing the burdens of the Israelites, suggesting a contrast with their previous suffering in Egypt.

Text: In your distress you called and I rescued you, I answered you out of a thundercloud; I tested you at the waters of Meribah.
Context: God reminds the Israelites that He heard their cries and delivered them, also referring to a time of testing (Meribah).

Text: Hear, O My people, and I will warn you— if you would but listen to Me, O Israel!
Context: God is calling for attention and obedience from His people, expressing a desire for them to heed His words.

Text: There shall be no strange god among you; you shall not bow down to a foreign god.
Context: This verse is a commandment against idolatry, reinforcing the first commandment to acknowledge only the God of Israel.

Text: I am the LORD your God, who brought you up out of Egypt. Open your mouth wide, and I will fill it.
Context: God reaffirms His identity and promise to provide for the needs of the Israelites.

Text: But My people did not listen to My voice; Israel would not submit to Me.
Context: This verse expresses God’s lament over Israel's disobedience and stubbornness.

Text: So I gave them over to their stubborn hearts to follow their own devices.
Context: God describes a consequence of Israel's disobedience by allowing them to pursue their own plans, which leads to their detriment.

Text: If My people would but listen to Me, if Israel would follow My ways,
Context: The verse reflects God's desire for Israel's obedience and the positive outcomes that would follow.

Text: how quickly I would subdue their enemies and turn My hand against their foes!
Context: The speaker, God, expresses a longing to protect and vindicate His people, conditional on their obedience.

Text: Those who hate the LORD would cringe before Him, and their punishment would last forever.
Context: The verse implies that the enemies of God and His people would face enduring consequences for their hostility.

Text: But you would be fed with the finest of wheat; with honey from the rock I would satisfy you.
Context: This verse promises abundance and provision from God to His people, symbolizing prosperity and satisfaction.
